bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George K. Strode, November 20, 1952

div1.p: Hench hopes that Strode, or one of his Rockefeller Foundation associates, will attend the Camp Lazear dedication. In his speech Hench plans to credit Finlay with the mosquito theory and Reed with its proof.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George K. Strode, November 20, 1952
div1.opener:
November 20, 1952
Dr. G. K. Strode
Director of International Health Division
Rockefeller Foundation
New York, New York
My dear Doctor Strode:
div1.p:
You may have heard that the Cuban Government has made a little park at
Walter Reed's Camp Lazear outside of Havana and are dedicating it to
the glories of Doctor Finlay, Major Reed and their colleagues on December 3,
Finlay's birthday which is “Physicians' Day in Cuba.” Although Doctor
Finlay will receive perhaps the major share of honors, nonetheless this is
a very gracious gesture on the part of the Cubans for this is the first
time they have ever honored Major Reed. I understand they propose to main-
tain the name Camp Lazear and that Reed's Building No. 1 will retain its
name also.

I believe that you and/or some of your associates will receive official
invitations to the affair, at least I hope so. The Surgeon General has
appointed General Paul H. Streit, Commanding General of Walter Reed Hospital,
as his official representative. The Mayo Foundation is sending me as its
representative. The ceremony will probably be a modest one in view of the
humble nature of Camp Lazear, but nevertheless it will be one of real
significance.

Doctor Strode, having been to Cuba often (see the enclosed reprint if you
care to do so), I know that as one of the speakers at the dedication I will
probably be interviewed by the patriotic Cuban press. Although I intend to
honor Finlay in full measure, I intend of course to make no retreats, to
speak of Finlay and his theory or conception and to speak of the proof of
Reed Reed and his associates. But you can fortify me or help me greatly
if you can answer for me one question. Have recent researches changed
materially Reed's formula for the development of yellow fever? I have
consulted your book but am not certain whether the data on page 443
represents modern thinking or refers to the old historical investigations.
You will remember that Reed's formula is as follows: The virus is in the
patient's blood for only the first three days and to become harmful it
must be incubated in the body of the mosquito for at least twelve to fourteen
days (see your book, page 548).

On page 443 of your book Taylor has written that the virus remains in the
patient's blood not over four to five days and that to be harmful it must
incubate in the mosquito for eight to twelve days.

If the latter represents definite modern thinking, the formula of Reed has
not been materially altered or at least not altered enough, so far as I can
see, to allow us to believe that any of Doctor Finlay's cases, by modern re-
interpretation, were of experimental (rather than natural) yellow fever. Is
that your understanding of the situation?

I realize that this is a crucial question and one contentious to the Cubans.
I propose to try to stay out of any arguments or discussions on it but it
would give me quiet courage if I had your advice in the matter and while I
expect to be able to avoid any unpleasant questioning, they may well ask
me the “$64 question”: “Have not modern researches shown that in all like-
lihood Doctor Finlay's cases were actually experimental yellow fever?”
Can you, unofficially and confidentially, back up my intended answer: “So
far as I know, the formula for the development of yellow fever as outlined
by Reed and his colleagues has not been changed sufficiently to permit us
to believe that Doctor Finlay's experiments were actually positive, even
though his theory was so eminently and brilliantly correct.”
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
